rename.from: [Request] Flag to keep the window and terminal open after the command returned

issue.title: Fix #1165 - Implement the "hold" feature
issue.body:
Hi there! Thanks a lot for your work on Alacritty, this project been helpful for me in countless ways, so I want to contribute something back. This PR implements `--hold` flag together with the `hold` configuration option which keeps Alacritty open after its child process exits.

Maybe I should clarify why I decided to put the `hold` flag in the `Term` struct instead of passing it directly to the `EventLoop` where the handling of child process exit happens. I've tried this approach first, but it turned out to be extremely hard to write a test for (at least for me, I'm a total noob in Rust). I've also tried ref-tests, but for some reason, even with just opening and closing Alacritty I get 60 megabytes of `grid.json`, and a generated ref test is always failing. I'm not sure why it happens as I'm not very familiar with how `Grid` works yet.

So I've taken the easy-to-test approach, I hope it's good enough :)

body:
I'd be interested why this feature would be added over just running the following:

```
alacritty -e sh -c "command && sleep infinity"
```

The original usecase mentioned in the issue seems a bit special to me, since it requires more than just holding the terminal and I don't see an advantage over just running the application directly in the terminal.

Wrapping everything in a shell call is possible, but then you need to carefully quote parameters and you lose the clean argument forwarding that `alacritty -e` does.

>I don't see an advantage over just running the application directly in the terminal.

If you're debugging a program that runs in the terminal (TUIs especailly) it's not really feasible.

> If you're debugging a program that runs in the terminal (TUIs especailly) it's not really feasible.

How is it not? I've done this myself before without any problems.

I think there's a misunderstanding here. Let's say you want to debug vim. If you just open `gdb vim` and do `run`, vim will take over the terminal so you can't interact with gdb anymore, and in addition you'll get rendering glitches as both programs try to write to the same terminal.
Possible solution are to either 
* attach gdb to vim after it's been launched
* open a blank terminal with `--hold` and tell `gdb` to open the debugged there. This is mostly what this issue is about.

I should also mention that solution #2 doesn't work if you do `tty && sleep infinity` since, as I mentioned, the terminal already has a "session leader".
At least this was my understanding at the time I opened this issue.

> open a blank terminal with --hold and tell gdb to open the debugged there. This is mostly what this issue is about.

Which terminal does this actually work in?

> possibly others

I don't think that's the usual behavior to be honest. At least not in any of the terminal emulators I've tested.

So this would be quite different from the conventional hold flag.
Could be; this was the advice I got from gdb folks on irc at the time.

I'm aware of attaching as you've noticed from my previous comment. It works until you want to debug some startup code. The second approach allows you to debug the complete execution of the program when it works.
